many aspiring political leaders are

for some of the problems we've been

we've been hearing about the loss of

they also think trade agreements

and I work in the middle of a highly

automobiles and even airplanes believe

let me give you an example a few months

that are manufactured in France and
they're assembled in Mexico using

those tail assemblies are done they're

all coming in to become a part of a new

economist Michael Porter described
what's going on here best many decades
ago he said that it's most beneficial
for a country to focus on producing
the products it can produce most
efficiently and trading for the rest so
what he's talking about here is shared
production an efficiency is the name of
the game you've probably seen an example
of this at home or at work let's take a
look at an example think about how your
house was built or your kitchen
renovated typically there's a general
contractor who is responsible for
coordinating the efforts of all the
different contractors an architect to
draw the plans a earthmoving company to

and so on so why doesn't the general
contractor pick just one company to do
all the work like say the architect
because this is silly the general
contractor selects experts because it
takes years to learn and master how to

some of them requiring special training
think about it would you want your
architect to install your toilet of
course not so let's apply this process
to the corporate world companies today
focus on manufacturing what they produce
best and most efficiently and they trade
for everything else so this means they
rely on a global interconnected
interdependent network of manufacturers
to produce these products in fact that
network is so interconnected it's almost
impossible to dismantle and produce
products in just one country let's take
a look at the interconnected web we saw

just one strand between the US and

share production represents 40% of the
half a trillion dollars in trade between

billion dollars or the same as the GDP

the u.s. decides to impose a 20% border

okay fine but do you think Mexico is
just gonna stand by and let that happen
no no way so retaliation they impose

could be looking at more than a 40

billion dollars don't kid yourself these

important increases in prices a Lincoln

sixty-seven dollars and the price of a

would go from thirteen dollars to
seventeen dollars now remember this is
only looking at one strand of the

so multiply this out across all of the
strands the impact could be considerable
now just think about this even if we
were able to dismantle this network and

which by the way is easier said than

we would still only be saving or

to the point where many of us can't

anyway the reality is that sure
production allows us to manufacture

it's that simple it allows us to get
more added limited resources and
